Technical Assistance Report
Project Number: 40120 
December 2006 
 
 
 
Asia Pacific Sustainable Development Summit 2007 
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Over  the  past  decade,  global  commitment  to  sustainable  development  has  been 
reaffirmed in extensive documentation and meetings at the highest political levels, strongly 
supported by the Asian Development Bank (ADB). At the 2006 Delhi Sustainable Development 
Summit (DSDS),1 it was agreed that ADB would be an appropriate organization to create a 
regional platform to continue dialogue on the sustainable development agenda. The proposed 
Asian  Sustainable  Development  Summit  (the  summit)  is  a  response  to  demands  from 
developing member countries (DMCs) to enhance ADB’s knowledge network to provide a global 
perspective on sustainable development issues in the Asia and Pacific region.   
 
2.  The scope and direction of the ADB technical assistance (TA) grant2 to support the 
proposed summit were defined in the concept paper approved by Management on 15 August 
2006. The TA is included as a firm activity in the work program of the Regional and Sustainable 
Development Department (RSDD) of ADB. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 
1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The concept and practice of sustainable development has gained increasing and urgent 
attention during the past few years, as the world begins to see more clearly the implications of 
the shrinking natural resources needed to support growing populations. It is not just that there 
will be more people, but that enormous changes in complex ecosystems—natural and human-
built—require significant technological innovations and adaptations in lifestyles now to meet the 
demands of coming generations. The Brundtland Report defined sustainable development as 
“development that meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future 
generations to meet their own needs”.3 That understanding was recently highlighted in the 
Millennium Ecosystem Assessment’s “stark warning” that “the ability of the planet’s ecosystem 
to sustain future generations can no longer be taken for granted” and that “resilience and 
abundance can no longer be confused with indestructibility and indefinite supply.”4 A recent 
report has an even more dire warning on the impending disastrous consequences of climate 
change, which is a key dimension of sustainability. The report asserts that climate change is 
“global in its causes and consequences [with] international collective action … critical [to] driving 
an effective, efficient and equitable response.”5 Reassuringly, despite political setbacks, there 
has  been  continuing  and  growing  responsiveness  of  governments,  corporations, 
nongovernment organizations (NGOs), and varied interest groups to address the sustainability 
issue. In the past few decades, responses to the challenges of sustainability have been evolving 
in several summits, forums, intergovernmental and nongovernment meetings, country policies, 
and multilateral and private sector initiatives devoted to sustainability issues.6

2   
 
4.   Sustainable development issues are being tackled on several intergenerational levels—
economic,  environmental,  social,  legal,  administrative,  scientific,  and  technological,  among 
others. There are many challenges to sustainable development on these levels, with key issues 
of global concern covering such areas as the management of natural resources, improving 
governance,  establishing  social  sustainability,  increasing  agricultural  productivity,  and 
addressing climate change.7 However, it is generally agreed that sustainability is not about 
balancing. Rather, it aims at multiple reinforcing gains with a combination of a limited set of 
fundamental,  broadly  applicable  requirements  for  progress,  and  considerations  specific  to 
location and context.8 The multidisciplinary dimensions of the problems also require global 
accountability for sustainable development. Sustainable development, then, “involves a process 
of deep and profound change in the political, social, economic, institutional, and technological 
order, including redefinition of relations between developing and more developed countries.”9 
That  process  requires  debate,  understanding,  and  exchange  of  ideas  among  leaders, 
development practitioners, civil society, and the private sector—at forums that will increase 
awareness  and  bring  together  countries  and  institutions  in  formulating,  financing,  and 
implementing action plans for all dimensions of sustainable development.  
 
5.  In ADB’s sphere of operations, the Asia and Pacific region is “vast and diverse, with … 
[Bangladesh, India, Indonesia, Pakistan and the People’s Republic of China] … accounting for 
two-thirds of all people living in rural areas without access to sanitation, underweight children, 
people living on less than a dollar a day, and of tuberculosis cases worldwide.”10 On the other 
hand, the Asia and Pacific region is the fastest growing and most dynamic region in the world. 
Among Asia’s impressive accomplishments over the past three decades are the doubling of its 
share of world gross domestic product (GDP), 30% increase in literacy rates, and increased life 
expectancy by over 20 years. Developing Asia is expected to grow by 7.7% in 2006, easing to 
7.1% in 2007, with the People’s Republic of China and India accounting for over 50% of regional 
GDP.11  
 
6.  Although the outlook for Asia is significantly optimistic, that has to be tempered with the 
concomitant strain on sustainability indicators. Asia remains on an unsustainable path with 
continuous population growth, widening income gaps, urban migration, and natural resource 
depletion. A recent report notes that, “… in the past quarter century, Asia has lost half of its 
forest cover and a third of its agricultural land has been degraded. Asia’s rivers contain three to 
four times more pollutants than the world average. Of the world’s 15 most polluted cities, 13 are 
in Asia … at least one in three Asians still has no access to safe drinking water, and one in two 
has no access to sanitation services … one-third of a billion tons of solid waste across Asia 
remains  uncollected  each  year  …  [and]  millions  of  tons  of  hazardous  waste  are  placed 
untreated in dumpsites, threatening groundwater and local food supplies.”12 Hence, Asia’s rapid 
economic growth is at risk because of high levels of resource inefficiency and dependence on

policy instruments and applications that are not evolving quickly enough to contain growing 
ecological damage. Ultimately, the poor will suffer most as they are most dependent on their 
environment for survival, and “the full potential of ecosystems as a wealth-creating asset for the 
poor—not just a survival mechanism—has yet to be effectively tapped.”13 With the evident 
linkages between poverty and the environment, global leaders continue to call for more action in 
tackling the disproportionately large impacts of environmental degradation on the poor.14 The 
right of the poor to enjoy environmental income may be increasingly characterized as one of 
Sen’s “instrumental freedoms”.15 
 
7.  Although there are worrisome trends in Asia’s ability to sustain the economic and social 
gains made over the past few decades, several regional initiatives have sought to achieve 
agreement on policy directions for sustainable development. These include (i) acid deposition 
and dust and sand storms in northeast Asia, (ii) haze control in southeast Asia, and (iii) trans-
boundary air pollution control in south Asia. ADB is also supporting regional cooperation through 
such initiatives as the Asian Environmental Compliance and Enforcement Network, Central 
Asian  Countries  Initiative  for  Land  Management,  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  Biodiversity 
Conservation Corridors Initiative, and Clean Air Initiative for Asian Cities (CAI-Asia). The private 
sector has also responded with “growing acceptance of the principles and practices behind the 
[United Nations] UN Global Compact for Corporate Citizenship, the Global Reporting Initiative, 
and the Equator Principles applied to large private investments.”16 
 
8.  As regional development challenges change rapidly, ADB has responded with marked 
changes  in  its  approach  and  operations  as  reflected  in  the  following:  (i)  reform  agenda; 
(ii) innovation and efficiency initiative; (iii) medium-term strategy II 2006–2008 (MTS II), which 
has adopted “Managing the Environment” as one of the five strategic priorities;17 (iv) other new 
initiatives (e.g., energy efficiency initiative); and (v) proposed review of the long-term strategic 
framework. Recently, ADB adopted a knowledge management framework in its efforts to evolve 
into  a  more  knowledge-based  organization.  It  has  also  emphasized  improved  internal 
networking, as evidenced by reorganization of the communities of practice.  
 
9.  As part of its efforts to strengthen external networking under a regional platform, ADB 
held  the  first  Asia-Pacific  Forum  on  Poverty  (February  2001),  which  brought  together 
intellectuals and development practitioners. There is a clear need to continue to draw on global 
and regional knowledge with intellectuals and development leaders, who would conduct high-
level discussions to generate new ideas and create stronger commitment to address emerging 
sustainability issues in the Asia and Pacific region. It was recently observed that “[sustainability] 
issues can only be dealt in an integrated, systematic manner; yet … policies, institutions and 
practices remain highly compartmentalized with only limited mechanisms for integration and 
cooperation. Nowhere is the need for an integrated approach to these issues more compelling 
than Asia.”18

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The  main  purpose  of  the  regional  technical  assistance  (RETA)  is  to  enhance 
coordination and harmonization among ADB, DMCs, and development partners on common 
directions for sustainable development in the Asia and Pacific region, and thereby make a 
substantive  contribution  to  efforts  to  achieving  Millennium  Development  Goals  (MDGs)  1 
(eradicate extreme poverty and hunger) and 7 (ensure environmental sustainability).  
 
11.  The growing pressure on Asia’s environmental capital is intense enough to justify a high-
level summit that would focus on reaffirming regional commitment to sustainability, accelerating 
the implementation of regional action plans where those exist, and adopting frameworks and 
actions plans for DMCs in which progress has been slow. The proposed summit would also help 
strengthen ADB’s external profile, and draw attention to ADB initiatives to develop its knowledge 
leadership in sustainable development issues and the mainstreaming of those efforts into its 
operations. The summit will bring together a range of stakeholders from the region and the 
world—global and regional leaders, academics, development practitioners, research institutions, 
developmental  organizations,  private  sector,  and  civil  society—to  discuss  emerging 
development trends and issues in the Asia and Pacific region. Discussions and deliberations in 
the summit will also contribute to ADB’s stock of knowledge, improve its knowledge networking, 
and benefit the region through knowledge generation and identification of key future issues of 
the region. The approach is consistent with the knowledge management framework, long-term 
strategic framework, and the reform agenda. The summit will have the following products and 
outcomes: 
 
(i)  a platform for intellectually strong discussion and consensus-building among key 
stakeholders in sustainable development; 
(ii)  review of Asian policies and programs contributing to sustainable development in 
the  region,  and  clear  recommendations  and  plans  of  action  to  improve  the 
effectiveness of such programs at both country and regional levels; 
(iii)  publication of a high quality knowledge product on summit outcomes; 
(iv)  high-quality documentation on trends and issues in selected sectors and themes 
for use by policy makers, private sector, civil society, other stakeholders, and 
ADB staff; 
(v)  visibility and demonstration of ADB’s knowledge leadership in the region with 
dissemination of knowledge products; and 
(vi)  enhanced partnership and expanded intellectual network for ADB. 
 
12.  Owing to the very wide diversity and complexity of sustainable development themes, the 
summit will (i) focus on issues of immediate importance to the Asia and Pacific region, and (ii) 
be framed in the context of ADB’s core operational sectors and priority areas identified under 
MTS II. Lead topics to be identified after interdepartmental discussions may include clean 
energy, sustainable use of natural resources, and livable cities.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.   The summit will involve plenary sessions, working sessions, briefings, and media events. 
The summit will be structured around the following:

5
(i)  Background papers. The summit will be preceded by the preparation of papers 
on lead topics, including an overall background paper, and technical papers for 
the individual working sessions, prepared by internationally recognized experts in 
sustainable development 
(ii)  The summit. The summit will involve a plenary session led by prominent leaders 
(e.g., current or former heads of states, ministers, senior public officials) of the 
region, and technical or working sessions on specific issues. 
(iii)  Summit  documentation.  The  main  speeches,  key  suggestions,  important 
outcomes of the discussions, and background papers prepared for the technical 
or working sessions of the summit will be compiled and edited as knowledge 
products.  Those  will  be  published  selectively,  internally  and  externally,  as 
appropriate. An overall high-quality knowledge product will be published, based 
on compilation of background technical papers prepared for discussion at the 
summit. Subsequently, the outcomes will be widely disseminated through the 
internet, various institutions, and the media using effective outreach materials. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $600,000. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s TA funding program. Details of the cost estimates and financing plan are in 
Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  ADB  will  be  the  Executing  Agency  and  RSDD  will  be  responsible  for  overall 
implementation  of  the  TA.  A  working  group  of  thematic  specialists  drawn  from  relevant 
departments will coordinate the selection of lead topics, review of technical papers, identification 
of  examples  of  good  practice,  and  general  thematic  directions  of  the  summit.  The  TA  is 
expected to commence in February 2007 and be completed by November 2007.  
 
16.  The summit will be held at ADB headquarters over 3 days during October 2007. It will 
begin  with  a  plenary  session  at  which  distinguished  global  leaders  and  development 
practitioners—representing developed countries, DMCs, development partners, civil society, 
and the private sector—will speak on sustainable development challenges in Asia. The plenary 
session will be followed by (i) parallel sessions on select topics relevant to DMCs and ADB, (ii) 
breakout sessions on approaches to meeting sustainable development challenges, and (iii) a 
concluding plenary session summing up the outcomes of the summit and identifying future 
actions and directions. Owing to the scale and level of participation at the summit, a consulting 
team (a firm or individual consultants) will be engaged for event coordination. Background 
papers on sustainable development by internationally recognized experts will be commissioned 
for the summit.  
 
17.  General terms of reference for conduct of the summit are in Appendix 3. All consultants 
will be selected and engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2006, as amended from time to time).  
 
III.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis for 
the Asia Pacific Sustainable Development Summit 2007, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.

ASIA PACIFIC SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT SUMMIT 2007 
GENERAL TERMS OF REFERENCE  
 
1.  The  Asia  Pacific  Sustainable  Development  Summit  2007  (the  summit)  will  have  the 
following objectives:  
(i)  Conduct a regional forum to discuss, debate, and adopt common directions on 
sustainable development issues in the Asia and Pacific region.  
(ii)  Engage distinguished experts and development practitioners in the preparation of 
technical papers related to the themes of the summit that will be endorsed by 
participants and be incorporated in Asian Development Bank (ADB) approaches and 
directions, intended to improve the effectiveness of its programs and operations. 
Detailed terms of reference for preparation of the papers will be drawn up based on 
interdepartmental discussions. 
(iii)  Produce outcomes in the form of high-quality publications, recommendations, and 
operationally relevant documentation for ADB and its developing member countries. 
(iv)  Generate  and  disseminate  knowledge  on  sustainable  development  issues  and 
approaches of most relevance to the Asia and Pacific region. 
(iv)  Provide general guidance to ADB on ways to achieve its medium- and long-term 
strategic objectives.  
2.  ADB will support the summit by  
(i)  facilitating  the  summit,  including  logistics,  documentation,  secretariat  services, 
dissemination of information and materials, and related support;  
(ii)  reimbursing selected participants for travel, hotel and per diem, and incidentals; and 
(iii)  financing the preparation of technical papers and post-summit publications 
3.  ADB will commission technical background papers by internationally recognized experts on 
sustainable development for discussion, debate, and analysis by participants at the summit. The 
experts will focus on areas of immediate concern to sustainable development issues in the Asia 
and Pacific region, and ADB’s core operational sectors and priority areas identified under the 
second medium-term strategy. Subsequently, ADB will publish knowledge products (high-quality 
summary reports, technical papers, and website briefings) that will be widely disseminated.  
4.  A  working  group  drawn  from  the  Regional  and  Sustainable  Development  Department 
(RSDD), communities of practice, and relevant regional departments will be established to identify 
(i) lead topics (e.g., clean energy, sustainable use of natural resources, and livable cities) for the 
summit; (ii) examples of good practice at ADB; (iii) terms of reference for consultants engaged to 
prepare background papers; and (iv) review of technical papers for the summit. The final structure 
of the summit will be based on those discussions to ensure that the themes and outcomes reflect 
(i) sustainable development issues of importance to the Asia and Pacific region, and (ii) ADB policy 
and operational linkages.
